Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: The carpenter should maintain a clean and organized work area
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my phone, feeling the familiar tug of anxiety. The team meeting was about to start in ten minutes, and my phone buzzed with reminders from my colleagues. They expected me to join, share updates, and be present—even if it was just a routine catch-up. I knew the meeting would be recorded, but I also knew how much my participation mattered to the team’s morale.

At the same time, I looked around the workshop. Sawdust covered the floor, and scraps of wood were scattered everywhere. As the lead carpenter, I was responsible for keeping the site safe and organized. If I left now to join the meeting, I’d be ignoring the safety protocols I drilled into my crew. A messy site could mean accidents, and I couldn’t shake the guilt at the thought of someone getting hurt because I wasn’t there to set the example.

My mind raced, torn between the expectations of my colleagues and my duty as a carpenter. I stood frozen, phone in one hand, broom in the other, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
